2134A - Painting With Two Colors

Hint 1

Check the parity of numbers aa, bb, and nn.

Solution

Let us first consider the bb blue cells. Since all bb cells appear in the final painting, for the coloring to be symmetric, they must be placed at the middle of the grid. Consequently, bb and nn must have the same parity.

Next, we examine two possible cases:

  • If b≥ab≥a, then the blue cells can fully cover all red cells. In this situation, the value of aa does not affect the final coloring.
  • If b<ab<a, then the red cells are not completely covered by the blue ones. Therefore, the red cells must also be placed in the middle of the grid, which means aa and nn must have the same parity as well.

Thus, by checking these conditions, we can determine whether a symmetric coloring exists. This requires only O(1)O(1) time.

Code (C++)
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n, a, b;
    cin >> n >> a >> b;
    if (a <= b) {
      cout << ((n % 2) == (b % 2) ? "YES\n" : "NO\n");
    } else {
      cout << ((n % 2) == (b % 2) && (n % 2) == (a % 2) ? "YES\n" : "NO\n");
    }
  }
}
Code (Python)
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n, a, b = map(int, input().split())
    if a <= b:
        if n % 2 == b % 2:
            print('YES')
        else:
            print('NO')
    else:
        if n % 2 == a % 2 and n % 2 == b % 2:
            print('YES')
        else:
            print('NO')

2134B - Add 0 or K

There are (at least) two solutions to the problem. Vote for your solution!

How did you solve the problem?
  • 563 ai←ai+k⋅(aimod(k+1))ai←ai+k⋅(aimod(k+1))
  • 403 Find a small prime number pp and make all elements divisible by pp
  • 58 Others
Hint 1

Find an integer g>1g>1 and integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn such that each ai+k⋅ciai+k⋅ci is divisible by gg.

Hint 2

Decide the value of gg only based on kk. There may be more than one possible choices.

Solution

The problem is equivalent to finding an array of nn non-negative integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn such that 0≤ci≤k0≤ci≤k for 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n and

gcd(a1+k⋅c1,a2+k⋅c2,…,an+k⋅cn)>1gcd(a1+k⋅c1,a2+k⋅c2,…,an+k⋅cn)>1

The idea is as follows. If we can find an integer g>1g>1 and integers c1,c2,…,cnc1,c2,…,cn such that each ai+k⋅ciai+k⋅ci is divisible by gg (for 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n), then the GCD condition is satisfied.

There are (at least) two ways to construct such a solution. The simplest solution is to take g=k+1g=k+1 and define ci=aimod(k+1)ci=aimod(k+1). This works because

ai+k⋅ci≡ci+k⋅ci≡(k+1)⋅ci≡0(modk+1)ai+k⋅ci≡ci+k⋅ci≡(k+1)⋅ci≡0(modk+1)

Hence every term is divisible by k+1k+1.

Alternatively, you can also find the smallest integer xx such that gcd(x,k)=1gcd(x,k)=1, and set g=xg=x. Note that g≤29g≤29, since k≤109k≤109 and the product of all prime numbers from 22 to 2929 already exceeds 109109.

Then, for each aiai, we can add kk to it until it becomes divisible by gg. In fact, the value of cici can be determined explicitly (though it is not required) as

ai+k⋅ci≡0(modg)⟹ci≡(−ai⋅k−1)(modg)ai+k⋅ci≡0(modg)⟹ci≡(−ai⋅k−1)(modg)

where k−1k−1 is the modular inverse of kk modulo gg.

Thus, in either method, we can always construct a valid array so that the GCD of the resulting numbers is greater than 11.

Code for solution 1 (C++)
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n, k;
    cin >> n >> k;
    vector<long long> a(n);
    for (auto &i : a) {
      cin >> i;
      i += (i % (k + 1)) * k;
    }
    for (auto i : a)
      cout << i << ' ';
    cout << '\n';
  }
}
Code for solution 1 (Python)
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n, k = map(int, input().split())
    a = list(map(int, input().split()))
    for i in range(n):
        a[i] += (a[i] % (k + 1)) * k
    print(*a)
Code for solution 2 (C++)
#include <iostream>
#include <numeric>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n, k;
    cin >> n >> k;
    vector<long long> a(n);
    for (auto &i : a) {
      cin >> i;
    }

    for (int g = 2;; g++) {
      if (gcd(g, k) != 1)
        continue;
      for (auto &i : a) {
        while (i % g != 0)
          i += k;
      }
      for (auto i : a)
        cout << i << ' ';
      cout << '\n';
      break;
    }
  }
}
Code for solution 2 (Python)
import math
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n, k = map(int, input().split())
    a = list(map(int, input().split()))
    for g in range(2, k + 2):
        if math.gcd(g, k) > 1:
            continue 
        ok = True
        b = list(a)
        for i in range(n):
            if b[i] % g == 0:
                continue
            for j in range(1, k + 1):
                b[i] += k
                if b[i] % g == 0:
                    break
            if b[i] % g != 0:
                ok = False
        if ok:
            print(*b)
            break

2134C - Even Larger

Hint 1

Only subarrays with length equal to 22 or 33 are useful.

Hint 2

Propose a greedy algorithm to decide which element to perform an operation.

Solution

For convenience, if nn is even, we append an+1=0an+1=0 to the end of the array. Note that an+1an+1 cannot be modified.

The first key observation is the following:

Observation. If all subarrays [al,al+1,…,ar][al,al+1,…,ar] with the following properties satisfy the condition, then all subarrays satisfy the condition:

  • r=l+2r=l+2,
  • ll and rr are both odd.

Proof. Consider such subarrays where both ll and rr are odd:

∑l≤i≤ri evenai≥=≥=∑l≤i≤ri even(ai−1+ai+1)al+⎛⎝⎜⎜∑l+2≤i≤r−2i odd2ai⎞⎠⎟⎟+aral+⎛⎝⎜⎜∑l+2≤i≤r−2i oddai⎞⎠⎟⎟+ar∑l≤i≤ri oddai∑l≤i≤ri evenai≥∑l≤i≤ri even(ai−1+ai+1)=al+(∑l+2≤i≤r−2i odd2ai)+ar≥al+(∑l+2≤i≤r−2i oddai)+ar=∑l≤i≤ri oddai

The second inequality holds because all numbers are non-negative.

Thus, checking only these subarrays is sufficient: all other subarrays will automatically satisfy the condition because they involve fewer elements at odd positions. □◻

We will call these subarrays important in the following discussion.

Now we find the minimum number of operations. Instead of directly minimizing the number of operations, we can think in terms of constructing the final array bb after the operations. Our goal is to maximize the sum of the elements in bb.

Initially, we set bi=0bi=0 for all ii. Notice that it is never beneficial to reduce values at even indices. Therefore, we can safely set bi=aibi=ai for every even ii.

The task is then to determine the values of bibi at odd indices. It turns out that the following greedy algorithm works:

  • Repeatedly pick the smallest odd index ii such that bi<aibi<ai, and increasing bibi by 11 does not violate the condition for any important subarray. Then increment bibi by 11.

This greedy algorithm ensures that we maximize the sum of bb while preserving validity. It can be simulated in O(n)O(n) time.

Code (C++)
#include <algorithm>
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n;
    cin >> n;
    vector<int> a(n);
    for (auto &i : a)
      cin >> i;

    vector<int> b(n + 1);
    long long ans = 0;
    for (int i = 0; i < n; i += 2) {
      int mn = a[i];
      if (i >= 2)
        mn = min(mn, a[i - 1] - b[i - 2]);
      if (i + 1 < n)
        mn = min(mn, a[i + 1]);
      b[i] = mn;
      ans += (a[i] - b[i]);
    }

    cout << ans << '\n';
  }
}
Code (Python)
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    a = list(map(int, input().split()))
    b = [0] * (n + 1)
    ans = 0
    for i in range(0, n, 2):
        mn = a[i]
        if i >= 2:
            mn = min(mn, a[i - 1] - b[i - 2])
        if i + 1 < n:
            mn = min(mn, a[i + 1])
        b[i] = mn
        ans += (a[i] - b[i])
    print(ans)

2134D - Sliding Tree

Hint 1

Consider the diameter of the tree. What do you discover?

Hint 2

Each sliding operation increases the diameter of the tree by at most 11.

Hint 3

Now about the construction. How to perform an operation at each step that increases the diameter by exactly 11?

Solution

We begin with the following observation:

Observation. Each sliding operation increases the diameter of the tree by at most 11.

Proof. Consider an operation (a,b,c)(a,b,c), any pair of indices (u,v)(u,v), and the unique path pp between uu and vv. If pp does not pass through bb, or if bb is an endpoint of pp, then the length of pp increases by at most 11 before and after the operation. Otherwise, let i1i1 and i2i2 denote the two neighbors of bb on the path pp. Then:

  • If i1=ai1=a and i2=ci2=c (or vice versa), the length of pp does not change.
  • If i1=ai1=a and i2≠ci2≠c (or vice versa), the length of pp increases by 11.
  • If i1≠ai1≠a and i2=ci2=c (or vice versa), the length of pp decreases by 11.
  • In all other cases, the length of pp does not change.

Thus, for any path in the tree, its length can increase by at most 11. Consequently, the diameter of the tree increases by at most 11 after a single operation. □◻

Let ll denote the diameter of the input tree. To transform it into a path graph (whose diameter is n−1n−1), it is clear that at least (n−1)−l(n−1)−l operations are required.

The remaining question is whether it is always possible to perform an operation at each step that increases the diameter by exactly 11. This turns out to be true. To see this, take any diameter of the tree and root the tree at one of its endpoints. In each operation, select an edge adjacent to the diameter. Suppose this edge is (u,v)(u,v), where uu lies on the diameter and vv does not. Then perform the operation with aa as the parent of uu (in the rooted tree), b=ub=u, and c=vc=v. One can verify that this increases the diameter by 11.

From the above construction, we conclude not only that the minimum number of operations is (n−1)−l(n−1)−l, but also that we can explicitly construct a sequence of operations that transforms the given tree into a path graph with this minimum number of moves.

Finally, finding the first sliding operation can be done in O(n)O(n) time.

Code (C++)
#include <algorithm>
#include <functional>
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n;
    cin >> n;
    vector<vector<int>> G(n);
    for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; i++) {
      int u, v;
      cin >> u >> v;
      u--, v--;
      G[u].push_back(v);
      G[v].push_back(u);
    }

    vector<int> dist(n), p(n);
    function<void(int, int)> dfs = [&](int now, int par) {
      p[now] = par;
      for (int i : G[now]) {
        if (i != par) {
          dist[i] = dist[now] + 1;
          dfs(i, now);
        }
      }
    };

    dist[0] = 0;
    dfs(0, -1);
    int x = max_element(dist.begin(), dist.end()) - dist.begin();
    dist[x] = 0;
    dfs(x, -1);
    int y = max_element(dist.begin(), dist.end()) - dist.begin();

    if (dist[y] == n - 1) {
      cout << -1 << '\n';
    } else {
      vector<int> on_diameter(n);
      int now = y;
      while (now != -1) {
        on_diameter[now] = 1;
        now = p[now];
      }
      int a = -1, b = -1, c = -1;
      for (int u = 0; u < n; u++) {
        for (int v : G[u]) {
          if (on_diameter[u] && !on_diameter[v]) {
            a = p[u], b = u, c = v;
            break;
          }
        }
        if (a != -1)
          break;
      }
      cout << a + 1 << ' ' << b + 1 << ' ' << c + 1 << '\n';
    }
  }
}

2134E - Power Boxes

Hint 1

An intuitive starting point may be to perform a throw query on every coordinate ii. For which ii we can decide the value of aiai immediately?

Hint 2

For those incides whose aiai is unknown, try to perform some swap queries on them to get the values of aiai for them.

Hint 3

No two unknown indices are adjacent.

Solution

An intuitive starting point is to perform a throw query on every coordinate ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n). Let didi denote the total number of jumps the ball makes when starting from coordinate ii. For convenience, define dn+1=dn+2=0dn+1=dn+2=0.

Notice that for 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, if di+1≠di+2di+1≠di+2, then we can immediately determine aiai: if di=di+1+1di=di+1+1, then ai=1ai=1; otherwise ai=2ai=2.

The difficult part of the problem is when di+1=di+2di+1=di+2. We call an index ii \textbf{unknown} if di+1=di+2di+1=di+2. In such cases, we can deduce didi without issuing a query, thus saving it for later use. The following observation is crucial:

Observation. No two unknown indices are adjacent.

Proof. If ii is unknown, then di=di+1+1di=di+1+1, hence di≠di+1di≠di+1. Therefore, i−1i−1 cannot be unknown. □◻

To exploit this fact, we adopt the following strategy: After computing all didi, for each unknown index ii (in increasing order), we swap the boxes at positions ii and i+1i+1, and then perform a throw query at coordinate i+1i+1. Since index i+1i+1 is not unknown, this reveals aiai. The special case is i=ni=n: here, we swap boxes n−1n−1 and nn, then perform a throw query on coordinate n−1n−1 to obtain anan.

To sum up:

  • For ii from nn down to 11: perform a throw query on coordinate ii. If di+1=di+2di+1=di+2, skip the query for ii and mark ii as unknown (but still compute didi). Otherwise, determine both aiai and didi.
  • For each ii from 11 to n−1n−1: if ii is unknown, swap box ii with box i+1i+1 and perform a throw query at coordinate i+1i+1. This reveals aiai.
  • Finally, swap n−1n−1 and nn, and perform a throw query on coordinate n−1n−1 to determine anan.

For every unknown index we use 22 queries, and for each known index we use 11. Since no two unknown indices are adjacent, there are at most ⌈n2⌉⌈n2⌉ unknown indices. Hence, the total number of queries is at most ⌈3n2⌉⌈3n2⌉.

Code (C++)
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    int n;
    cin >> n;

    vector<int> a(n);
    auto swap = [&](int x) {
      cout << "swap " << x + 1 << endl;
    };
    auto throw_ball = [&](int x) {
      cout << "throw " << x + 1 << endl;
      int ret;
      cin >> ret;
      return ret;
    };
    auto answer = [&]() {
      cout << "!";
      for (auto i : a)
        cout << ' ' << i;
      cout << endl;
    };

    vector<int> jumps(n + 2);
    for (int i = n - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
      if (jumps[i + 1] == jumps[i + 2]) {
        jumps[i] = jumps[i + 1] + 1;
      } else {
        jumps[i] = throw_ball(i);
        if (jumps[i] == jumps[i + 1] + 1)
          a[i] = 1;
        else
          a[i] = 2;
      }
    }
    for (int i = 0; i + 1 < n; i++) {
      if (a[i] == 0) {
        swap(i);
        int jumps_i = throw_ball(i + 1);
        if (jumps_i == jumps[i + 2] + 1)
          a[i] = 1;
        else
          a[i] = 2;
      }
    }
    swap(n - 2);
    int jumps_last = throw_ball(n - 2);
    if (jumps_last == 2)
      a[n - 1] = 1;
    else
      a[n - 1] = 2;
    answer();
  }
}

2134F - Permutation Oddness

Thanks to Misuki for coming up with a better solution! My original solution has a much larger constant.

Hint 1

Consider two groups of numbers; one is 0,20,2 and another is 1,31,3. What do you discover?

Hint 2

Consider the segments formed by 0,20,2 (same for 1,31,3). For each ii and jj, find the number of ways to arrange them into ii segments so that the total number of adjacent pairs inside all segments contribute oddness jj.

Hint 3

Enumerate all binary strings consisting of c0c0 zeros and c2c2 twos. Then split these strings into several substrings.

Hint 4

Brute force over the number of runs of the binary string. Find the contribution to the count.

Solution

Consider any rearrangement bb. We color all elements bibi with value 00 or 22 as red, and those with value 11 or 33 as blue. Then the array can be viewed as alternating red and blue segments.

We observe the following:

  • Adjacent pairs within a red segment contribute 00 or 22 to the oddness. The same holds for blue segments.
  • Adjacent pairs between red and blue segments contribute exactly 11 to the oddness.
  • The number of red and blue segments differs by at most 11.

Hence, if we can calculate the following:

  • ri,jri,j: number of ways to arrange c0c0 zeros and c2c2 twos into ii segments, so that the total number of adjacent pairs inside all segments contribute oddness jj.
  • Similarly define bi,jbi,j for the blue digits (11 and 33)

Then the final answer can be computed in O(n3)O(n3) by performing convolutions between the arrays pairs (ri,bi),(ri+1,bi),(ri,bi+1)(ri,bi),(ri+1,bi),(ri,bi+1).

Now about computing ri,jri,j. This reduces to counting tuples of ii binary strings formed from c0c0 zeros and c2c2 twos, such that the total number of alternating adjacent pairs inside them equals jj.

The idea is as follows. First, enumerate all binary strings consisting of c0c0 zeros and c2c2 twos. Then split these strings into several substrings.

Suppose a binary string has ll runs. Let l1=⌈l2⌉l1=⌈l2⌉ be the number of runs of 00, and l2=l−l1l2=l−l1 the number of runs of 22 (or vice versa). The number of such binary strings is

(c0−1l1−1)⋅(c2−1l2−1)(c0−1l1−1)⋅(c2−1l2−1)

In such strings, there are l−1l−1 adjacent pairs with different numbers, and c0+c2−lc0+c2−l adjacent pairs with the same numbers.

Now split the string into several substrings. Assume we choose k1k1 positions among the l−1l−1 differing adjacencies, and k2k2 positions among the c0+c2−lc0+c2−l equal adjacencies. The number of ways to do this is

(l−1k1)⋅(c0+c2−lk2)(l−1k1)⋅(c0+c2−lk2)

This partition produces k1+k2+1k1+k2+1 substrings, each contributing oddness 2⋅(l−1−k1)2⋅(l−1−k1).
Thus, the contribution to rk1+k2+1,2⋅(l−1−k1)rk1+k2+1,2⋅(l−1−k1) is

(c0−1l1−1)⋅(c2−1l2−1)⋅(l−1k1)⋅(c0+c2−lk2)(c0−1l1−1)⋅(c2−1l2−1)⋅(l−1k1)⋅(c0+c2−lk2)

Enumerating all possible tuples (l,k1,k2)(l,k1,k2) suffices to compute all ri,jri,j. This computation takes O(n3)O(n3) time.

By the same process, we can compute bi,jbi,j in O(n3)O(n3). Finally, convolving the results yields the number of distinct permutations for each oddness value. The entire algorithm runs in O(n3)O(n3) time.

Code (C++)
#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

constexpr int MAXN = 800;

// Modified from https://github.com/ToxicPie/NaCl
template <typename T> struct M {
  constexpr static T MOD = 1'000'000'007;
  T v;
  M(T x = 0) {
    v = (-MOD <= x && x < MOD) ? x : x % MOD;
    if (v < 0)
      v += MOD;
  }
  explicit operator T() const { return v; }
  bool operator==(const M &b) const { return v == b.v; }
  bool operator!=(const M &b) const { return v != b.v; }
  M operator-() { return M(-v); }
  M operator+(M b) { return M(v + b.v); }
  M operator-(M b) { return M(v - b.v); }
  M operator*(M b) { return M((long long)v * b.v % MOD); }
  M operator/(M b) { return *this * (b ^ (MOD - 2)); }
  friend M operator^(M a, int b) {
    M ans(1);
    for (; b; b >>= 1, a *= a)
      if (b & 1)
        ans *= a;
    return ans;
  }
  friend M &operator+=(M &a, M b) { return a = a + b; }
  friend M &operator-=(M &a, M b) { return a = a - b; }
  friend M &operator*=(M &a, M b) { return a = a * b; }
  friend M &operator/=(M &a, M b) { return a = a / b; }
};
using Mod = M<int>;

int main() {
  ios::sync_with_stdio(false);
  cin.tie(0);
  vector<vector<Mod>> binom_(MAXN + 1, vector(MAXN + 1, Mod(0)));
  for (int i = 0; i <= MAXN; i++)
    for (int j = 0; j <= i; j++) {
      if (j == 0 || j == i)
        binom_[i][j] = 1;
      else
        binom_[i][j] = binom_[i - 1][j] + binom_[i - 1][j - 1];
    }
  auto binom = [&](int x, int y) {
    if (x >= y && y >= 0 && x >= 0)
      return binom_[x][y];
    else
      return Mod(0);
  };

  int t;
  cin >> t;
  while (t--) {
    vector<int> cnt(4);
    for (auto &i : cnt)
      cin >> i;
    int n = cnt[0] + cnt[1] + cnt[2] + cnt[3];

    vector<vector<Mod>> r(n + 1, vector(n + 1, Mod(0))),
        b(n + 1, vector(n + 1, Mod(0)));

    auto fill_table = [&](int x, int y, vector<vector<Mod>> &table) {
      for (int i = 2; i <= x + y; i++) {
        vector<pair<int, int>> segments;
        if (i & 1)
          segments = {{i / 2, i - i / 2}, {i - i / 2, i / 2}};
        else
          segments = {{i / 2, i / 2}, {i / 2, i / 2}};
        for (auto [l1, l2] : segments) {
          if (x < l1 || y < l2)
            continue;
          auto mul = binom(x - 1, l1 - 1) * binom(y - 1, l2 - 1);
          int different = i - 1, same = (x + y) - 1 - different;
          for (int j = 0; j <= different; j++)
            for (int k = 0; k <= same; k++) {
              auto mul2 = binom(different, j) * binom(same, k);
              int c = different - j;
              table[j + k + 1][c] += mul * mul2;
            }
        }
      }
    };

    fill_table(cnt[0], cnt[2], r);
    fill_table(cnt[1], cnt[3], b);

    vector<Mod> ans(2 * (n - 1) + 1);
    for (int i = 1; i <= (n + 1) / 2; i++)
      for (int j = 0; j <= n; j++)
        for (int k = 0; k <= n; k++) {
          int oddness = (j + k) * 2 + (i * 2 - 1);
          if (oddness >= 0 && oddness <= 2 * (n - 1))
            ans[oddness] += r[i][j] * b[i][k] * 2;
        }
    for (int i = 1; i <= (n + 1) / 2 && i + 1 <= n; i++)
      for (int j = 0; j <= n; j++)
        for (int k = 0; k <= n; k++) {
          int oddness = (j + k) * 2 + i * 2;
          if (oddness >= 0 && oddness <= 2 * (n - 1)) {
            ans[oddness] += r[i][j] * b[i + 1][k];
            ans[oddness] += r[i + 1][j] * b[i][k];
          }
        }

    for (int i = 0; i <= 2 * (n - 1); i++)
      cout << ans[i].v << " \n"[i == 2 * (n - 1)];
  }
}

        0

        Sorry for the late reply, but it seems that we can solve F in O(n2logn)O(n2log⁡n) time with an adaptation from maspy's write-up.

        Let's define r′i,jri,j′: number of ways to arrange c0c0 zeros and c2c2 twos into ii segments, so that the total number of adjacent pairs inside all segments is jj.

        Let's calculate r′i,jri,j′ in increasing order of ii. For i=1i=1 it's easy. For i>1i>1, we try to take a combination of i−1i−1 segments and make one more split to make ii segments. We have the following formula:

        r′i,j=(j+1)⋅r′i−1,j+1+(c0+c2−1−j)⋅r′i−1,jri,j′=(j+1)⋅ri−1,j+1′+(c0+c2−1−j)⋅ri−1,j′

        This is simply the addition of two cases whether the split happens at an adjacent pair with same/different numbers.

        However r′i,jri,j′ is not the real count. We have to divide it by i!i! because we overcount each way of splitting by i!i! times.

        Therefore ri,jri,j can be calculated in O(n2)O(n2) time and the whole algorithm runs in O(n2logn)O(n2log⁡n) time.

+9

For D, we can construct the whole operation sequences in O(n)O(n).

Code
auto Paint = [&](int r, int k) -> std::pair<std::vector<int>, std::vector<int>> {
    std::vector<int> mark(n + 1);
    std::vector<int> list;
    auto dfs = [&](auto&& self, int now, int from) -> void {
        for (auto nxt : edg[now]) {
            if (nxt == from) continue;
            self(self, nxt, now);
            mark[now] |= mark[nxt];
        }
        if (mark[now]) list.push_back(now);
    };
    mark[k] = 1;
    dfs(dfs, r, -1);

    return {mark, list};
};
auto [h, list] = Paint(a, b);// a, b is the end point of the diameter

std::vector<std::array<int, 3>> ans;
auto work = [&](int v, int f) {
    std::vector<int> vis;
    vis.push_back(f);

    auto dfs = [&](auto&& self, int now, int from) -> void {
        vis.push_back(now);
        for (auto nxt : edg[now]) {
            if (nxt == from || h[nxt]) continue;
            self(self, nxt, now);
        }
    };

    dfs(dfs, v, -1);

    for (int i = 2; i < vis.size(); i++) {
        ans.push_back({vis[i - 2], vis[i - 1], vis[i]});
    }
};

for (int i = list.size() - 1; i; i--) {
    work(list[i], list[i - 1]);
}

And implement the checker in O(nlog2n)O(nlog2⁡n)

Part of checker
#include<bits/stdc++.h>
#define int i64 /* R.I.P */
#define all(x) std::begin(x), std::end(x)
#define rall(x) std::rbegin(x), std::rend(x)
using i64 = long long;
using u64 = unsigned long long;
using ld = long double;

#define LINE std::cerr << __LINE__ << "}\n";

void solve() {
    int n;
    std::cin >> n;
    std::vector edg(n + 1, std::set<int>());

    for (int i = 1; i < n; i++) {
        int x, y;
        std::cin >> x >> y;
        edg[x].insert(y);
        edg[y].insert(x);
    }

    std::vector<int> mp(n + 1), rmp(n + 1);
    std::iota(mp.begin(), mp.end(), 0);
    std::iota(rmp.begin(), rmp.end(), 0);

    auto calc_Diameter = [&]() -> std::array<int, 3> {// diameter, a, b
        auto getdis = [&](int r) {
            std::vector<int> dis(n + 1, 1e9);

            std::queue<int> q;
            q.push(r);
            dis[r] = 0;
            while (q.size()) {
                int now = q.front(); q.pop();

                for (auto nxt : edg[now]) {
                    if (dis[nxt] > dis[now] + 1) {
                        dis[nxt] = dis[now] + 1;
                        q.push(nxt);
                    }
                }
            }
            return dis;
        };
        
        auto d0 = getdis(1);
        int a = 1;
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            if (d0[i] > d0[a]) {
                a = i;
            }
        }

        auto d1 = getdis(a);
        int len = d1[1];

        int b = 1;
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            if (d1[i] > d1[b]) {
                b = i;
                len = d1[i];
            }
        }
        
        return {len, a, b};
    };

    auto [len, a, b] = calc_Diameter();

    auto show = [&]() {
        std::cout << "==========\n";
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            std::cout << mp[i] << " ";
        } std::cout << "\n";
        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            std::cout << rmp[i] << " ";
        } std::cout << "\n";

        for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            for (auto j : edg[mp[i]]) {
                if (i < rmp[j]) {
                    std::cout << i << "-" << rmp[j] << "]\n";
                }
            }
        }

        std::cout << "==========\n";
    };

    auto Range_Vaild = [&](int v) -> bool {
        return v >= 1 && v <= n;
    };
    auto Edge_Vaild = [&](int a, int b) -> bool {
        return edg[mp[a]].contains(mp[b]);
    };
    auto check_vaild = [&](std::vector<std::array<int, 3>> ans) -> bool {
        for (auto [a, b, c] : ans) {
            // show();
            // std::cout << a << ", " << b << ", " << c << "]\n";
            if (!Range_Vaild(a)) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer a's range invaild";
                return 0;
            }
            if (!Range_Vaild(b)) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer b's range invaild";
                return 0;
            }
            if (!Range_Vaild(c)) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer c's range invaild";
                return 0;
            }
            if (a == b) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer a should not be equal to b";
                return 0;
            }
            if (b == c) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer b should not be equal to c";
                return 0;
            }
            if (a == c) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer a should not be equal to c";
                return 0;
            }
            if (!Edge_Vaild(a, b)) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer edge (a, b) does not exist before the current operation";
                return 0;
            }
            if (!Edge_Vaild(b, c)) {
                std::cout << "wrong answer edge (b, c) does not exist before the current operation";
                return 0;
            }

            if (edg[mp[b]].size() < edg[mp[c]].size()) {
                for (auto nxt : edg[mp[b]]) {
                    if (rmp[nxt] == a || rmp[nxt] == c) continue;
                    edg[mp[c]].insert(nxt);
                    edg[nxt].insert(mp[c]);
                    edg[nxt].erase(mp[b]);
                }
                edg[mp[b]].clear();
                edg[mp[b]].insert(mp[a]);
                edg[mp[b]].insert(mp[c]);
            } else {
                std::swap(mp[b], mp[c]);
                rmp[mp[b]] = b;
                rmp[mp[c]] = c;                

                for (auto nxt : edg[mp[b]]) {
                    edg[mp[c]].insert(nxt);
                    edg[nxt].insert(mp[c]);
                    edg[nxt].erase(mp[b]);
                }
                edg[mp[b]].clear();

                edg[mp[a]].erase(mp[c]);
                edg[mp[c]].erase(mp[a]);
                edg[mp[c]].erase(mp[c]);

                edg[mp[b]].insert(mp[a]);
                edg[mp[a]].insert(mp[b]);
                edg[mp[b]].insert(mp[c]);
                edg[mp[c]].insert(mp[b]);
            }            
        }
        // show();
        return 1;
    };

    if (n - 1 - len == 0) {
        std::cout << -1 << "\n";
    } else {
        auto Paint = [&](int r, int k) -> std::pair<std::vector<int>, std::vector<int>> {
            std::vector<int> mark(n + 1);
            std::vector<int> list;
            auto dfs = [&](auto&& self, int now, int from) -> void {
                for (auto nxt : edg[now]) {
                    if (nxt == from) continue;
                    self(self, nxt, now);
                    mark[now] |= mark[nxt];
                }
                if (mark[now]) list.push_back(now);
            };
            mark[k] = 1;
            dfs(dfs, r, -1);

            return {mark, list};
        };
        auto [h, list] = Paint(a, b);// a, b is the end point of the diameter

        std::vector<std::array<int, 3>> ans;
        auto work = [&](int v, int f) {
            std::vector<int> vis;
            vis.push_back(f);

            auto dfs = [&](auto&& self, int now, int from) -> void {
                vis.push_back(now);
                for (auto nxt : edg[now]) {
                    if (nxt == from || h[nxt]) continue;
                    self(self, nxt, now);
                }
            };

            dfs(dfs, v, -1);

            for (int i = 2; i < vis.size(); i++) {
                ans.push_back({vis[i - 2], vis[i - 1], vis[i]});
            }
        };

        for (int i = list.size() - 1; i; i--) {
            work(list[i], list[i - 1]);
        }

        assert(ans.size() == n - 1 - len);
        assert(check_vaild(ans));

        std::cout << ans[0][0] << " " << ans[0][1] << " " << ans[0][2] << "\n";
    }

    auto [len_, _, __] = calc_Diameter();
    if (len_ != n - 1) {
        std::cout << "wrong answer after all operation the tree is still not a path graph\n";
    }
}

signed main() {
    std::cin.tie(0) -> sync_with_stdio(false);
    int t = 1;
    std::cin >> t;
    while (t--) solve();
    return 0;
}

If the problem D is changed to this, how would it be rated in the cf rating?

      Consider this: you want all of the indices aiai to have some common factor. So, you can either add 0 or add k to aiai. Hence, we can say that ai←ai+ci∗kai←ai+ci∗k where cici depends on what aiai is. Now one observation that can be made is that if you take ci=aimodk+1ci=aimodk+1, you can write your new assigned aiai as ai+(aimodk+1)∗(k+1−1)ai+(aimodk+1)∗(k+1−1) which further simplifies to (ai−(aimodk+1))+(k+1)∗(aimodk+1)(ai−(aimodk+1))+(k+1)∗(aimodk+1) which you can see is divisible by k+1k+1. So, we can assign such an aiai to each of the element, so that that it becomes divisible by k+1k+1. Also notice our factor with k is aimodk+1aimodk+1 which is less than or equal to kk, so we are at most only doing k operations.

    I am not sure what coprimes are, but the goal is to find a common divisor (factor) for all of b.

    Lets say we try some x. If x is a (prime) factor of k, then adding k to b, (where k % x==0) will not change the remainder.

    Hence, you have to find a prime p which is not a factor of k (k % p !=0). Thereby you are guaranteed to change the remainder and it will at some point be divisible by p.

    Since k<10**9, you only need to try primes up to 30 or so.

    When you have X and K as coprime, and a number A!

    If you keep adding K to A and take modulo X then you'll see that, within X additions, you would have covered all the range 0 to X — 1.

    ← Rev. 2 →  
    0

    The goal is to make GCD of all the elements = k + 1. So, in the end each a[i] % (k + 1) = 0. Suppose initially a[i] % (k + 1) = x. Then x belongs to [0, k].

    If x = 0, then we do not need to add k during any of the k operations. Else, if k != 0 then (a[i] + k) % (k + 1) = x — 1. Therefore, every time you add k to a[i] the modulo (k + 1) decreases by 1. Since a[i] % (k + 1) can be at most k, if you keep adding k for a[i] % (k + 1) times then it will become 0. And, a[i] % (k + 1) can be at most k.

    +5

    We are not using n throw queries first. We can know which indices will be unknown and can skip them. Let u be the no. of unknown indices, the total ops will be: n-u throws + u swaps + u throws = n + u. u can be at most n/2, so it turns out to be <= 3n/2

Please tell me if my approach for Problem D is correct or not

My approach for D The best operation would be: To do the operation from a node with degree > 2 in the direction of the leaf node. Since there could be multiple combinations of leaf nodes and nodes with degree > 2, we need to choose the combination that has the minimum distance between the leaf node and the node with degree > 2.

To find the best combination, I am using BFS simultaneously from all the leaf nodes, and as soon as I encounter any node with the maximum degree, I return the BFS for that particular combination. This, I believe, is O(n) time complexity because I don't add any node in the queue twice.

In my approach b --> node with maximum degree (>2) c --> either a leaf node (if the leaf node is directly connected to b), or a directly connected node in the direction of the leaf node (computed above using BFS) a --> It will be any node directly connected to b (doesn't matter)

But, my solution is getting TLE on TC-2 (335747332)

I believe my solution's time complexity is O(n). Please correct me if I am wrong (Currently, I am not worried if my approach is correct or not; I am more worried about why my solution is giving TLE)

    Try to see that, if the condition of A[i] >= A[i — 1] + A[i + 1], holds true for all such possible values of 2 <= i <= N — 1, then no matter what subarray size you take, it'll never be violated.

    During Update you just need to make sure the gap of A[i] — (A[i — 1] + A[i + 1]), should be first used to reduce the A[i + 1] to the very extreme untill it reaches zero if it's possible, so that you can get the benefit for the later 3 length subarray segment {A[i], A[i + 1], A[i + 2]}

In editorial for 2134B - Add 0 or K the statement "take k+1k+1 as gg" seems not very trivial to me, but note {0.k,…,k.k}{0.k,…,k.k} is a complete residue system modulo k+1k+1, which means by adding these to a set of numbers you can always make them divisible by k+1k+1. That's how I got it. maybe you find it useful.

I have a slightly different solution for problem E that only does one pass.

Start by finding anan and an−1an−1. Also find an−2an−2 if nn is odd. This can be done in 33 or 55 operations. (always query n−1n−1).

Now assume you know didi and di+1di+1. You want to use at most 33 queries to find ai−1ai−1 and ai−2ai−2 (and then find corresponding dd).

Case 1: di=di+1⟹di=di+1⟹ query i−2i−2. If the answer is di+1di+1 then ai−2=2ai−2=2, otherwise it is 11. Swap i−2i−2 and i−1i−1 and redo the query. In total we have 33 queries.

Case 2: di≠di+1⟹di≠di+1⟹ query i−1i−1. If the answer is didi then ai−1=2ai−1=2, otherwise it is 22. Swap i−2i−2 and i−1i−1 and redo the query. In total we have 33 queries.

You figured out 22 values in 33 queries. The total is 3n23n2 for even nn and 3n+123n+12 for odd nn.

This is basically the same solution given in the editorial, but only one pass is required.

I wonder if there is a strategy that can do better in general (i.e. no matter the original configuration do at most ⌈3n2⌉−1⌈3n2⌉−1)

I solved 2134B - Add 0 or K using a slightly different approach.

Let's recall gg as some integer >1>1 such that each ai+k⋅ciai+k⋅ci is divisible by gg then:

ai+ci⋅k≡0 (mod  g)ci⋅k≡−ai (mod  g)ai+ci⋅k≡0 (mod  g)ci⋅k≡−ai (mod  g)

Now, we need to apply Fermat's Little Theorem. So, gg and kk must be coprime.

ci≡−ai⋅k g − 2 (mod  g)ci≡−ai⋅k g − 2 (mod  g)

The immediate value for gg that came to my mind is k+1k+1 as gcd(k, k+1)=1gcd(k, k+1)=1. So,

ci≡−ai⋅k k − 1 (mod  k+1)ci≡−ai⋅k k − 1 (mod  k+1)

Then the smallest cici that satisfies the equation is (−ai⋅kk − 1) % (k+1)(−ai⋅kk − 1) % (k+1), and the final answer is:

ai←ai+[(−ai⋅kk−1)  %  (k+1)]∗kai←ai+[(−ai⋅kk−1)  %  (k+1)]∗k

I hope my explanation is clear :) I know that I overthink it, but this is the first approach that came to my mind, and it took me a lot of time to verify during the contest.

Problem E is clever!

I will write down my initial approach, which gives correct answer, but exceeds the query limt (at max 2n−12n−1 queries) Observations: (1)(1) It is easy to see that throwing at coordinate n−1n−1, will directly reveal an−1an−1 (infact its given as hint 1) (2)(2) If jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2]jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2], then we can determine aiai in exactly one query. (3)(3) If we write down jumps[i]jumps[i], then if jumps[i]=jumps[i+1]⟹jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2]jumps[i]=jumps[i+1]⟹jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2]

Now, my algo was as follows: 1) Query thrown−1thrown−1 [uniquely determines an−1an−1 from observation (1)(1) ] 2) Perform swapn−1swapn−1 and thrown−1thrown−1, this will determine anan and jumps[n]jumps[n] 3) For i=n−2to1i=n−2to1, if jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2]jumps[i+1]≠jumps[i+2], query throwithrowi and get ai,jumps[i]ai,jumps[i], else : swapiswapi, and query throwi+1throwi+1 and get aiai.

The trouble? It exactly follows the observations as the editorial, but in the worst case, it can go in the else part of step 3, for every ii, thus giving 2n−12n−1 queries :(

Spoiler

Consider when a=[1…1n−1 times2]a=[1…1⏟n−1 times2], my described algo will hit 2n−12n−1 queries exactly.

Though, my idea and observations were the same, but this way you would exceed queries :(

    My solution is quite similar to yours but doesn't exceed query limit. It is easy to show that if throws[i + 1] == throws[i + 2] then a_{i-1} can be determined in one query.

    Mine is

    1) Find out a_n and a_{n-1} in the same way as you.

    2) Then for i = n — 2 to 2:


           if throws[i + 1] != throws[i + 2]

           determine a_i in one query

           continue

       else

           throw i - 1

           update a{i-1}

           swap i - 1

           throw i - 1

           update a{i}

           i = i - 1

    Similarly determine a_1 in the case of odd n.

    Since I either use 1 query per element or 3 queries for 2 elements. The total queries is bounded by ceil(3n/2).

    Code

    This fails on TC140 in Test 2 and I have no idea why.

    Can someone help me fix it?

    If you know jumps[i+2] and jumps[i+3], you can work out positions i and i+1 in 3 operations:

    • If jumps[i+2] == jumps[i+3], you can work out position i, swap positions i and and i+1, and work out the new value at position i once more.
    • If jumps[i+2] != jumps[i+3], you can work out position i+1, swap positions i and and i+1, and work out the new value at position i+1 once more.

    This uses 3 queries for every 2 values.

    At the end we might might be left with position 1 if n is odd, but we have two queries to play with. If jumps[2] != jumps[3], we can query position 1 directly, otherwise we swap positions 1 and 2 and query the new position 2 (as jumps[3] and jumps[4] must be different in this case).

    Note that we can set jumps[n+1] = jumps[n+2] = 0 to make things easier.

    This is how I thought during the contest:

    Consider ai≡x(mod(k+1))ai≡x(mod(k+1)), where 0≤x≤k0≤x≤k. Now, observe that k≡−1(mod(k+1))k≡−1(mod(k+1)). Thus, adding kk each time will result in the mod lowering by 1. x→x−1→…0→k→…x→x−1→…0→k→… (since we can use at most kk operations, it is guaranteed we will hit 00 exactly once).

    Hence, if you find ai+x⋅k≡ai−x(mod(k+1))ai+x⋅k≡ai−x(mod(k+1)) (which will be equal to 00 (mod (k+1k+1)))

    For example: consider ai=117,k=11ai=117,k=11, clearly 117≡9(mod12)117≡9(mod12), hence 117+9×11=216≡0(mod12)117+9×11=216≡0(mod12).

    I hope that is clear.

    Let x = a[i] mod (k+1), and note that k = -1 mod (k+1).

    a[i] + k * (a[i] mod (k+1))
= a[i] + k * x  mod (k+1)
= x + k * x  mod (k+1)
= x - x  mod (k+1)
= 0  mod (k+1)

        The key observation / thing to know is that k = -1 mod (k+1), e.g. 4 = -1 mod 5 or 999 = -1 mod 1000. And if we have have a remainder of x we can make it 'disappear' by adding x times -1.

+3

I have a solution for problem E that seems slightly simpler in my opinion: going backwards from n to 1, consider pairing adjacent indices, and we will attempt to solve the values for each of the pairs in 3 queries. If n is odd, we shall simply try to solve for i=1 in 2 queries after having solved for the rest of the indices.

I maintain two arrays, val[1..n] and dp[1..n + 2], where val[i] is the value of the i th index and dp[i] corresponds to the value of the throw(i) (in the current hidden array configuration) for i <= n, and dp[n + 1] = dp[n + 2] = 0.

I also maintain the list of swaps that are made, and in the end I shall go in the reverse order of this list to restore the original array.

For each pair (i + 1, i) belonging to {(n,n-1), (n-2,n-3)..( ,2 or 1)} we calculate val[i] and val[i + 1] by observing the following:

  • if dp[i + 2] == dp[i + 3], then
    • if throw(i) == dp[i + 2] + 1, then val[i] must be 2. Else val[i] must be 1.
    • We swap i and i + 1, and again we ask throw(i) to get the new val[i] that corresponds to the previous val[i + 1]. We also assign the previous val[i] to the new val[i + 1]
  • if dp[i + 2] != dp[i + 3]
    • if throw(i + 1) == dp[i + 2] + 1, then val[i + 1] must be 1. Else val[i + 1] must be 2.
    • We swap i and i + 1, and again we ask throw(i + 1) to get the new val[i + 1] that corresponds to the previous val[i]. We also assign the previous val[i + 1] to the new val[i]
  • We compute dp[i] and dp[i + 1] using dp[i + 2], dp[i + 3], val[i] and val[i + 1]

If n is odd, we have 2 queries left to use for ascertaining val[1].

We notice that either dp[2] != dp[3] or dp[3] != dp[4]

(proof by contradiction: if dp[2] == dp[3] == dp[4], but val[2] = 1 or 2, which means dp[2] == 1 + dp[3] or 1 + dp[4], which contradicts the original assumption).

If dp[2] != dp[3], we simply ask throw(1) and if it equals 1 + dp[2], then val[1] == 1. If it is not equal to 1 + dp[2], then val[1] == 2.

If dp[2] == dp[3], then dp[3] != dp[4]. So we first swap the values at indices 1 and 2, and then query throw(2) to determine the value of the new val[2] which corresponds to the previous val[1]. If throw(2) == 1 + dp[3] then val[2] == 1 else val[2] == 2.

There is a small mistake in the editorial for D.

If pp does not pass through bb, or if bb is an endpoint of pp, then the length of pp clearly does not change before and after the operation.

If bb is an endpoint of pp and pp does not pass through aa or cc, the length of pp will increase by one.

Consider the figure above. Suppose pp is the unique path between nodes 33 and 22. After applying the operation 44, 33, 22; the length of pp changes from 22 to 33.
